articles.headline: Lost in Arizona Fire, an Elite Crew That Rushed In
articles.snippet: The deaths of 19 men, most of them young, in a fierce wilderness fire stunned a local community that viewed them as heroes.
articles.abstract: The deaths of 19 men, most of them young, in a fierce wilderness fire stunned a local community that viewed them as heroes.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRESCOTT, Ariz. — The men were mostly born and bred in this city on the mountains, surrounded by thick forest of piñon pine and chaparral brush, parched by years of drought. They were young men, mostly, 14 of them in their 20s — outdoorsmen, fathers, heroes to the local high school athletes they themselves once were.

articles.headline: Zynga Hires Xbox Boss to Initiate Turnaround
articles.snippet: Zynga, the struggling social games maker, said its founder and chief executive, Mark Pincus, will be replaced by Don Mattrick, the head of Microsoft’s Xbox business. Mr. Pincus will remain at Zynga as chairman and chief product officer.
articles.abstract: Zynga, the struggling social games maker, said its founder and chief executive, Mark Pincus, will be replaced by Don Mattrick, the head of Microsoft’s Xbox business. Mr. Pincus will remain at Zynga as chairman and chief product officer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Zynga, the social games maker that has stumbled badly over the last year, said it had replaced its founder and chief executive, Mark Pincus, with the head of Microsoft’s Xbox video game business, Don Mattrick.

articles.headline: The Essential Wall St. Summer Reading List
articles.snippet: The best business books offer dramatic narratives, provide a grounding in economic history or help explain the thinking inside the corner office.
articles.abstract: The best business books offer dramatic narratives, provide a grounding in economic history or help explain the thinking inside the corner office.
articles.lead_paragraph: If there is one question I am consistently asked every summer, it is this: What’s the best business book that I should be reading?

articles.headline: Few Signs of a Taste for Diet Pills
articles.snippet: Qsymia, a weight-reduction drug, had sales of only $4 million in the first quarter. Its manufacturer is trying to jump-start acceptance of the drug.
articles.abstract: Qsymia, a weight-reduction drug, had sales of only $4 million in the first quarter. Its manufacturer is trying to jump-start acceptance of the drug.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans spend tens of billions of dollars each year to lose weight — gym memberships, Weight Watchers and other programs, operations, nutritional supplements and whatever the latest diet fad might be.

articles.headline: Winklevoss Twins Plan First Fund for Bitcoins
articles.snippet: A proposal by Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss to create an exchange-traded fund dealing in bitcoins could make the digital currency more accessible to ordinary investors.
articles.abstract: A proposal by Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss to create an exchange-traded fund dealing in bitcoins could make the digital currency more accessible to ordinary investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bitcoin has been promoted as an alternative crypto-currency that exists outside the realms of governments and central banks. Now, two backers of the digital money are seeking to bring bitcoin into the investing mainstream — if they win the approval of the United States government.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: Loan Practices of China’s Banks Raising Concern
articles.snippet: Regulators say banks have been profiting by offering wealthy Chinese high returns on loans, with banks lending the cash to companies unqualified for loans otherwise.
articles.abstract: Regulators say banks have been profiting by offering wealthy Chinese high returns on loans, with banks lending the cash to companies unqualified for loans otherwise.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Text message solicitations began arriving on the mobile phones of many of China’s wealthy last month, promising access to lucrative wealth management products with yields far above the government’s benchmark savings rate.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Groups Offering Cover for Lawmakers on Immigration
articles.snippet: As the push to overhaul the immigration system has made Senator Marco Rubio and other Republicans pariahs among some rank-and-file, well-financed forces in the G.O.P. have begun running interference.
articles.abstract: As the push to overhaul the immigration system has made Senator Marco Rubio and other Republicans pariahs among some rank-and-file, well-financed forces in the G.O.P. have begun running interference.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fox News viewers in Florida will see a new commercial in the coming weeks urging them to call Senator Marco Rubio. “Thank him for keeping his promise, and fighting to secure the border,” a narrator says in the ad, which is paid for by the conservative American Action Network.

articles.headline: Chaos in Middle East Grows as the U.S. Focuses on Israel
articles.snippet: As protests roil the Middle East, Secretary of State John Kerry’s focus on talks between the Israelis and Palestinians has raised questions about the administration’s priorities.
articles.abstract: As protests roil the Middle East, Secretary of State John Kerry’s focus on talks between the Israelis and Palestinians has raised questions about the administration’s priorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In Damascus, the Syrian government’s forces are digging in against rebels in a bloody civil war that is swiftly approaching the grim milestone of 100,000 dead. In Cairo, an angry tide of protesters again threatens an Egyptian president.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Jodi Rudoren

articles.headline:
Morsi Defies
Egypt Army’s
Ultimatum to
Bend to Protest
articles.snippet: With his political isolation deepening, President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt demanded late Tuesday that the military rescind its ultimatum against him.
articles.abstract: With his political isolation deepening, President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt demanded late Tuesday that the military rescind its ultimatum against him.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — President Mohamed Morsi rejected an ultimatum in an angry speech Tuesday night as Egypt edged closer to a return to military rule.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Ben Hubbard
